posts.name: Kevin Shaw
posts.cooked:
Hello  
We are considering adding a CNC Break to our toolset. We use 0.125 aluminum in our designs and typically order sheet metal from FabWorks. The prices from FW are not bad but the time-to-delivery is often 7+ days for us making it prohibitive.  

Our goals are several-fold: introducing students to metal bending designing for it shortening turn-time so that we use sheet metal more often expanding our use of sheet metal since I view it as a core capability reducing mass for robot mechanisms.  

We tend to use a lot of tube stock in our robot designs since it gives us easy 90-degree surfaces. And it is a powerful technique but I think sheet metal can be lighter allow more design freedom and might be simpler.  

After this year's champs we visited Robonauts (What a shop!) and saw their Langmuir Titan 25T CNC Break. It looks like we can get one with a reasonable set of tooling/fixtures for about $9K.  

Questions:  
How valuable is a break for FIRST Robotics Competition design?  
Can you recommend a good break for 1/8" aluminum?  
Do you have the Titan 25T and if so do you recommend it?  

Thank you.  
Kevin Shaw  
Head Coach, Team 3045 Gear Gremlins

link_counts.title: Change one letter of a thread title

posts.cooked:
The text is:  
The Spectrum 3847 Build Blog 2025 team discusses sheet metal brakes, mentioning issues with the Wazer Pro compared to the Wazer Desktop. The Wazer Pro excels in aluminum processing up to 1/8 inch but needs attention for thicker materials beyond short periods. A common malfunction is backflow sensor issues, which can often be fixed with a few seconds adjustment. Mentioned individuals include @Wittry, @AllenGregoryIV, @rstockton429, and @R.C., discussing the pros and cons of the Wazer Pro. Another participant references the Titan25t, asking about CNC press brake usage. Multiple threads continue the conversation about these products and their performance.

posts.name: RedLeader342
posts.cooked: i think having sheet metal capabilities is way better than not. i don’t know if you need a CNC machine, a normal one would do just fine. you just have to be good at layout. but i guess if you have the funds available and don’t need to spend it on other things, why not?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E.

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked: Kevin We have a titan25t. It’s a solid machine and if you have spare funds I’d definitely grab one. To curb expectations it’s not as good as a Trumpf or Amada or even the higher end Chinese brake presses but it still does the job. We bent all the 1323 parts in house this year and enjoy the flexibility of bending random stuff.

posts.name: Ryan Stockton
posts.cooked:
The Langmuir Titan 25T CNC brake system represents a significant leap forward in sheet metal bending technology, particularly for hobbyists and professionals in industries like FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC). While it shares a higher price tag compared to dedicated industrial machines, its advantages lie in its simplicity, reliability, and versatility. Unlike more advanced systems such as Amada or Trumpf, the Titan excels in cost-effectiveness and ease of use, though it may require more precise setup and testing compared to industrial-grade presses.

Key features highlight its adaptability for various applications, including FRC robots. The system includes a comprehensive set of tools, such as dies and punches tailored to different material thicknesses, enabling users to bend parts accurately even for challenging geometries. The inclusion of optional enhancements like LED bracket holders and precision adjustments further extends its capabilities, offering greater customization and control.

One notable aspect is the system's performance compared to manual bending methods. It provides consistent results, reducing the reliance on skilled operators for every bend. However, its lower resolution compared to industrial machines means it may not achieve the same level of precision for extremely complex designs. Despite this trade-off, the Langmuir Titan remains an excellent choice for projects where budget and ease of use are priorities.

For those considering an upgrade, detailed purchasing guides and technical specifications are readily available, including lists of required components and tooling. Additionally, supplementary resources like video tutorials and design recommendations provide further assistance in maximizing the system's potential. Overall, while the Titan may not match the performance of professional-grade systems, it offers a practical solution for hobbyists and teams seeking reliable, affordable sheet metal bending solutions.

posts.name: JJ Sessa
posts.cooked:
We have a Titan25T. It’s a solid machine, and if you have spare funds, I’d definitely grab one. To curb expectations, it’s not as good as a Trumpf or Amada or even the higher-end Chinese brake presses, but it still does the job.

Helped RC tool this one out, and I gotta say, I was really impressed by the specs and the parts they made on this—it’s crazy how you can get anything in the ballpark of what we can do for 1/50th the cost of our Trumpf TruBend…

If any FIRST Robotics Competition teams end up getting a Titan25T or similar CNC brake, please take it very seriously. These machines are an order of magnitude easier to injure yourself on than other equipment most have in an FIRST Robotics Competition shop. These entry-level machines are missing tons of safety features that our industrial brakes have. Our press brakes are the only piece of equipment I wouldn’t feel comfortable having our kids run around with, as brakes require a certain level of finesse to operate safely.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: If any FRC teams end up getting a Titan25T or similar CNC brake, handle it with care. These machines are significantly easier to injure oneself on compared to typical equipment found in an FRC shop. Is that because of snapping or unexpected objects flying free? Or because a hefty press with a sharp bit could remove digits? Calculations suggest the force required to bend 1/8-inch 6061 aluminum is far greater than what’s needed to break a hand, indicating the latter reason.

posts.name: Kevin Shaw
posts.cooked: Yes, I would like to hear more on the safety issues too.

posts.name: Kevin Shaw
posts.cooked: Thank you for the amazing response. You answered an unspoken question: what dies and punches do we actually need? I had guessed at some but this gets me a realistic set. Thank you! Also, the slide deck is excellent. I would love to hear the commentary that goes with it.

posts.name: RedLeader342
posts.cooked: I do agree with this but the price gap between a decent manual brake and the Langmuir CNC sheet metal brake isn't as big as it used to be. We have had this Baileigh manual brake for years and it has been great but takes a lot of test bends and quite a bit of time to dial in bends. It costs $4,200. We got the Langmuir Titan 25T in February when we lost access to NASA sheet metal bending. We ordered all of the accessories and all of the tooling available for just under $10,000 (Prices have gone up a bit since then). more than double the price? And that's a manual brake that has all the fancy bits. While this may be smaller than it used to be, it's still an enormous gap for most teams.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E.

posts.name: JJ Sessa
posts.cooked: Modern machines require precise settings based on the specific tooling and materials used; setting the maximum tonnage just above what’s needed prevents overloading small parts. Tooling for high-end applications is heat-treated to harden only the bending surfaces, preventing explosions and cleanly splitting under overload. Bending lifts the part upward, necessitating careful positioning; our machines include a light curtain to halt operations during unintended movements and a programmed sequence to allow operators sufficient time before the machine completes the bend.

posts.name: Mike Marandola
posts.cooked: Is that because of “snapping and/or sending stuff flying unexpectedly” or “several ton press with relatively sharp bit on it will remove digits”? We’ve had someone break their fingers at work by not paying attention and getting them pinched in between the part and the ram of the brake when bending a C-shaped part. It comes up on you quickly.

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: CNC break? I sure hope it doesn’t!

posts.name: topgun
posts.cooked: We have had this Baileigh manual brake for years and it has been great but takes a lot of test bends and quite a bit of time to dial in the bends. How thick of aluminum did you bend on this brake? Its rated for 16 gauge mild steel. Thank you for the write-up!

posts.name: Ryan Stockton
posts.cooked: We have bent up to 1/8-inch aluminum on it (not at full width) and have also bent 3/16-inch polycarbonate on it.

posts.name: Kevin Shaw
posts.cooked: Thank you. For the polycarb, I believe you need to heat the material while bending it. Is it challenging to heat the material considering the steel punch, or should the punch be heated instead? I think it cracks if not heated properly. Do you have any thoughts?

posts.name: Ryan Stockton
posts.cooked: The team initially attempted to bend 3/16" polycarbonate parts directly using a manual brake, but found that it often resulted in cracking due to sharp radii on the dies. To address this, they developed a method involving sacrificial sheets placed under the main parts, allowing for a larger bend radius and preventing cracking. This technique was successfully applied to both 3/16" polycarbonate and aluminum parts, demonstrating its effectiveness. While CNC brakes offer higher precision, their complexity makes the process more demanding. Notably, the primary intake structure on their 2023 robot was constructed using this method, showcasing its adaptability across different materials and applications.

posts.name: Jeremiah Johnson
posts.cooked: Polycarb is a fantastic material. It can be bent cold very easily. I’ve cold bent many pieces of 1/4" up to 90° on a manual pan brake. It’s generally recommended to bend cold at 90° or less and bend 20-40° past the desired final bend angle to account for spring back. Cold bending over 90° may exceed the elastic limit and preheating the bend line can prevent that. Increasing the bend radius will also reduce the risk of cracking.
